Which is exactly why you do it in public, if she has any decency she would try and remain calm without causing a scene, it also gives you an easy out without it turning into a screaming match.

Long story short, do it in a quiet public place, keep it short and concise and leave asap. Cut her out your life straight after, meaning you block and delete her number and socials. This will help you both move on, for her sake as well

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28346699
This may not be the answer that you want, but I'm not sure that you're asking the right question.

There are a number of possible explanations for this. Maybe he doesn't care about you. Maybe he does but is just a bit useless - forgetful, bad at organising things. Maybe the two of you like to express affection in very different ways: I don't know if you have tried one of those "love languages" quizzes, but different things matter more to different people - some are more focused on physical affection (touch and hugs), some on some on doing things for the person they love ("acts of service"), some on material gifts, some on verbal declarations, some on spending "quality time" together, etc. It could be that the ways the two of you tend to express affection aren't very compatible with what you both want.

But what I think you should be asking is, does it actually *matter* what the explanation is? You're obviously not happy in your relationship right now; you aren't getting what you want and need from it; you aren't feeling loved. You've tried talking to your bf about it, more than once if I understand correctly, and nothing has changed. So, regardless of what the explanation is, it seems very likely that things are going to continue the way they've been going up to this point, and you're thing to continue to be unsatisfied.

So, you aren't happy, and things probably aren't going to change. Doesn't that mean you would be better off leaving your bf and being with someone else who gives you the things that you need? And isn't that true irrespective of why he's behaving like this? I don't think it matters very much *why* your bf is not giving you what you need; all that matters is that he isn't, and that probably isn't going to change. That's really all you need to know.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28346953
>I can't just dump him
I understand what you're saying; and I do realise that finding a boyfriend may be much more difficult for you than it might be for others, and that you don't want to be alone. But as someone who is a lot older than you, with considerable experience of both good and bad relationships, I can tell you that there are much worse things than being alone.

Yes, the guy doesn't hit you, but "a guy who doesn't hit you" isn't setting the bar very high, is it? (I've been trying to avoid metaphors in case you have the type of autism that makes them difficult for you, but hopefully you understand what I mean by that!)

It really isn't very difficult to find a man who wants to cuddle you. And there are negatives about being with the wrong guy. One thing that does significantly concern me about your original post is the part about him denying that the two of you agreed to do something when you clearly did. There are several possible malevolent explanations for this; there are some others that just involve him being really forgetful or a bit of an idiot; but either way, the psychological impact on *you* is not trivial. Practically, this is what people call "gaslighting". It is possible that he didn't consciously intend it that way; but the effect on you is going to be exactly the same either way. It might seem odd to say that someone can be "unintentionally abusive", but they actually can - I've been in a relationship that was like that - and in the long term, the impact on you of him doing things like that will be quite severe.

Obviously, I don't know you, and there's a limit to what I can figure out about you from a few paragraphs; but from what I can tell, I think it's very likely that you underestimate yourself, and that you would, in fact, find it easier to find a decent man to be with than you think you would. And I think you ought to try. (FWIW, if I were much nearer your age, you sound like someone I might want to try dating!)

>>28342968
>I've spent so much time stfu'ing and learning throughout college
The learning in college and the learning in the workplace are two different types.
College is mostly hard skills. Hard skills that can be taught to any monkey, with the point of completion being that you've proven you can sit your monkey ass down long enough in an organized setting in an attempt to better yourself without as much external influence.
Professional environments are about utilizing those hard skills just enough to get your job done within the frame of company politics. The politics at most white collar jobs are heavily influenced by maintaining the status quo. Not fucking up is often the equivalent of succeeding. There's probably at least 2 senior people checking your working and unfucking it (or downplaying your fuckups to management). That's on top of the people that have already figured out the best/practical way to do something before it hits your desk.
You're the grunt. The people above you are too tired to churn out work and (usually) wise enough to know how to not fuck it up. You'll get more accolades when you're no longer the grunt.
>chance to do something
Then start your own business. Seriously. You know all those tired, wise people I talked about above? There are a shit ton of them with a shit ton of money, which they are willing to give to you if you put in the work.

>>28331977
Tim Fletcher on youtube has a lot of useful videos and info. Robert Sapolsky has a ton of videos on behaivoural psychology, his video on depression being caused by fighting with yourself has been really useful.

Start keeping a diary and working on practicing cognitive restructuring and memory refactoring. Asking questions like
>What is [x] Emotion?
>When was the first time I felt [x] way?
>What does this situation remind me of?

Etc will help work through the BS. Expect the executive functioning issues to get worse before they get better. Tons of cognitive restructuring worksheets online. The memory refactoring is simpler, just know you are focusing on a congruent lifelong birth to now narrative that makes sense, and that it doesn't have to make sense to other people, just you. People naturally find hazardous memories ridiculous, it's a defense mechanism. They need you to be crazy so they don't have to deal with the idea of the possibility of the "crazy" situation happening to them complicating their lives like it has yours. Each memory, or narrative, doesn't have to be perfect, and as you remember them and add and remove details and reinterpret them and grow, you will go through the 7 stages of grief over and over and over. It's a massive pain in the ass. Only you can deal with the empirical experience in your life, other people can't. If you can work with a complex ptsd clinic all the better. I've also found Diane Langberg's speeches useful.

The biggest things you can do right now is focus on keeping your living space clean, getting a CPAP to treat sleep apnea if you're overweight, focusing on diet, and staying off drugs even if it's caffiene. Get yourself some multivitamins, magcal, vitamin C, Iron, D and Zinc and get in the habit of asking yourself at the end of the day if you had enough calcium and iron and supplimenting with that. Twinlabs has the best vitamins IMO. D and Zinc you should have on-hand to help when you get sick.

BTW, regrowing your brain is likely to take years, but god is it rewarding to not have to deal with constant guilt\shame\fear, uncontrollable circular thinking, etc. It is the most exhausing thing I have personally ever done and I've put in some long fucking hours at jobs.

I used to have a messy room, and bad depression. For me, cleaning my room helped a lot. You can start bit by bit if you're too overwhelmed with the stuff. Today you can clean your bed, tomorrow maybe a corner of your room. I throw stuff away I know I'm never going to use, or you can donate them as well.

Then after you're done cleaning your room, maybe you can ask your family for therapy or something. Having an emotional support system while being at your lowest is important (I'm assuming your folks decent people and not abusive).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28332562
It happens over time in the background as you go through the cognitive restructuring.

Somedays I've worken up and realized something, other days it takes a lot of caffiene and thinking it through. Some days are easy, others are really hard. And there's a lot of repetition of the same things over and over especially where it comes to perceptional templates or schema's, which are basically things your parents or society tought you that you take for assumptions. E.G. My mother didn't have the concept of being loved until she had children, then she got that concept of unconditional love from the baby and didn't let us form boundaries early on, and that fucked up my head. Those kinds of things are a real bitch.

Like you wake up and realize all of the standards the specific society you are in are bullshit because the people producing the standards, statistically, have not experienced a single traumatic event in their families. You remember times of going to the hospital with your parent after they were gravely injured and seeing a family huddled and praying around their elderly, and recognize that for what it is; people who are functional enough to form social bonds. These are the yuppie freaks of nature, they have no appreciation for the history they have come from because putting themselves in the shoes of their ancestors seems so far fetched. 50% of all people born never made it to the age of 18, death used to be everywhere, and these people have no concept of that and for them to understand that requires they grow as a person in ways that are not obvious to them now. They take their days for granted.

Over time, you heal, and stop being in such dire straights. Best part is once you've gotten out of the morass your perception is way, way better than the average persons, and you enjoy the little things in life more.

Just doing the cognitive restructuring causes the brain to grow, and it is by far the most exhausting thing I've ever done.

Basically what happens is you get into that state then begin ignoring it to be functional (self abandonment), and go into a state known as hyperarousal where your body never really rests. I've had the hyperarousal, not fun to never be able to rest. Been dealing with sleep apnea issues as of late but I remember years ago my self-abandonment had gotten bad enough I didn't ever feel like I needed to urinate.

As far as the guy, he was born in the right place at the right time to an employee owned company and he's a mechanical savant. Dude just kept constantly working on machines, teaching himself, digesting books, going to the library, just constantly worked and happened to have a really good group of people to work with. Was really blessed to work with him for a few years. He had started contracting at the place I worked and e-mailed everyone gearing from a sealed gearhouse that had been chewed up due to electrolysis (so much electricity was flowing through the frame of the machine that the metals inside began reacting with eachother through the lubricants inside of the gear house) and I mentioned to him it looked like electrolysis and he should check the grounding. Came over to my desk 3 minutes later with a chechire cat grin on my face and then told the GM I was the only person there who know what the fuck was going on. They installed hundreds of 15ft grounding rods after that, fixed a lot of issues.

>>28339988
Also one other thing to note and consider is to Look at Reactive Attachment Disorder.

The default social relationship between a baby and a caregiver is that of a paternal figure, so if a baby doesn't have a parent and is neglected or abandoned and manages to survive that, the default social interaction they will have is thinking everyone is their parent. Ergo:

>Codependant people are people who were neglected\abandoned and responded with a flight\freeze response.

>Narcissists are people who were neglected or abused and responded with a fawning response to get resources, and don't feel bad about it because everyone is their parent and they are deserving, and if they manage to survive, this produces a warped sense of self-aggrandization.

> Sociopaths are people who who were abused and responded with a fight response, and they fight everyone, and everything, to get what they need or want but in a social way.

> Psychopaths are sociopaths with no empathy.

> ASPD Can be any of the aformentioned groups except codependants and are socially predatory. Narcissists for example don't generally choose narcisism, but if they go down the path ignoring their empathy for personal gain, may rely on narcissism to avoid the impact of losing empathy.

Wanting to help everyone for your entire life can be a codependant fawning behaivour stemming from parental abandonment and not feeling like you belong. Take a few steps back and ask why.

I help people mainly because because nobody helped me, but also because it's an intellectual pursuit that I enjoy. I have seen a lot of shit, and helping people helps me keep that in perspective.

Not that anon, but I'm 27 and in a similar situation as you. I only work about 5hrs a week and earn more than most of my friends combined. I have too much free time, whereas they don't. I've started going out solo to bars and clubs during the weekend and have had great success. I usually drink some vodka at home before heading out to call my nerves, and once I get to the bar/club (much easier in a bar to converse), I usually sit in a table and scope out the area. Once I finish my first drink, I approach the bar and make conversation with the bartender (can be literally about anything, this is to make it seem like you're friendly to the people around you, smile when you can and throw in a couple laughs here and there). Once I get my drink, if there's anyone near me I find attractive/approachable, I do the same thing. I just go up to them and compliment their looks, ask their opinion on something random, or just ask if I can join them and offer to pay for a round (surprisingly, this will oftentimes get you drinks paid for by them). You just have to get out there and do something. Staying couped up in your place nets you a zero percent chance of talking to someone and getting laid. At least when you step out and go to one of these places, that chance is now >0%. On days where I just wanted to wind down and sip on drinks, both women and men have come up to me and started a conversation. By simply putting yourself out there, your chances of interaction will never be 0%.

In my case the problem wasn't that I didn't get hungry, it was that when I did, I ignored it until the feeling passed.

Personally, I made an effort to stop ignoring it and started forcing myself to eat something small at normal eating times. Now I'm eating more or less like a normal person.

Not exactly your situation, I know, but if you've got no psychological reason for not being hungry, it's worth a shot.

posts.com:
So Ive been dealing with a bunch of shit and I'm just tired at this point. Health, work, family, world events, ect.

Ive been trying to keep it together while doing what I ought to be doing but it just seems so stupid with my best never being enough and i'm beating myself up that i can't get out of the hell i'm in.

I just had a breakdown at my job, knee jerk emotional reaction -instant apology and owned up and took accountability but got sent out despite seeing others repeatedly doing worse, in my opinion. I may loose my job and I don't have a healthy support network to turn to.

I completely broke down when I got home and just felt my heart snap.

I feel like a part of me has given up completely, walls are too high, expectations unrealistic and efforts don't translate into the changes i been pushing for.
But a small part of me is still refusing to throw it in, I realized I never really given myself a chance to let go, and just truly feel broken and emotional on my own terms, its always a reaction to whats around me. I'm always holding the truthful screams and tears inside. Even now I feel like a husk that will just continue on taking hit after hit because nothing else works.

Its not original, but I wanted to see the stars, the milky way and just be alone and scream and mourn my lost childhood and life at the world, maybe at myself, or for myself. IDK but something inside is telling me to wander far far off for my own sake.

Idk I'm hoping the experience could change something in me or help me heal in some way.

I have about 800 dollars to my name and Im trying to figure out a way to get from Michigan to somewhere, I don't own a car so I will have to bus. this would be the first "trip" I ever took for myself and I dont have a concrete plan, I do have camping gear but I don't want to feel like this is a survival expedition, I just want time for myself.

Thoughts or advice on how to get this rolling asap?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Do what you want to do.
Plan a long weekend/week away on a hiking trip, bring your camping gear etc. Spend no more than $100 bucks on it all in. Do your soul searching, find your purpose, your passion, your goal.
Then come back to reality and make a plan to survive.
If it's out of state or otherwise whatever, plan a job upon arriving in the new place, anything will do to begin with, something you can survive for a year or two. Depending on your answers from your time away from the world you pick classes/courses/education based upon what you want to do and do them in your off time and realise your dreams.
I believe in you anon, it'll all work out, I promise.

posts.sub: Thinking of what could have been is killing me
posts.com:
I'm really feeling down in the dumps, I don't know who to talk to about this.

Also some parts of the story might not make sense because I'm trying to obfuscate some parts for anonymity. Some parts of the story are intentionally vague.

This is a bit of a long story and I don't really know where to start, so I'm just going to start with when I met her. It was at college and I worked as a student helper for a class. There was this girl in the class that would ask for a lot of help and was over the top nice to me. She would do things that I would definitely consider way outside of "normal" nice. My initial impression of her was that this girl just had a bubbly nice personality, but as the semester progressed she kept doing way over the top "nice" things. This lead to my impression to change from "oh, shes just a nice girl" to "oh, shes just sucking up for a grade". But it continued to get more over the top personal, she would come and talk to me about things that I would not even tell my friends, and she was talking about it to a random guy. I even started wondering if she was just using me as a therapist. I don't remember who asked for whos number but eventually we had eachothers phone number and she would send walls of text messages to me with again over the top "niceness", and would continually do over the top "nice" things in person. Nothing physical.

It honestly got to the point where I felt very annoyed with her. Partly because I did finder her very attractive, yet unable/unwilling to ask her out, and also because I felt she was being nice just for the grade. At one point I even straight up told her that almost everyone in the class gets an A, in an effort to get her to stop.

More in comments

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28346566
After that work relationship ended, I still had classes with her where we were just classmates, so I just started ignoring her. Wouldn't even look at her. She noticed this and also stopped talking to me in class (for the most part).

Even after all this, she would still occasionally send wall of text messages to me and stuff, with the same energy of being super nice. After college, I didn't see her again, but she did message 1 or 2 times after.

I honestly did not care about this situation at all, unless very recently when I was having a conversation with one of my friends about college stuff and told them this story of an annoying girl in my class, that he pointed out that the story sounds like the girl was just interested in you. It was a puzzling moment because it genuinely, absolutely genuinely first time it ever occurred to me that maybe this girl had a thing for me.

I can't put into words how much pain this "what if" has caused me, and it's for a multitude of reasons.

1) If my interpretation of her actions had been wrong, and she was actually just a kind person, then this girl had done some of the kindest things to me that anyone has done. I'm very afraid to write here the specifics because I'm paranoid but they are definitely high effort and very personal things. And I treated her horribly. Many situations I could have helped her, and intentionally chose to avoid her and do nothing. (to elaborate on this point, I did whatever was required of me as a job, but for pretty much all other students I would go the extra mile and help them out in a lot of different ways).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28346571

2) As a person, if I think of what "type" of girl I'm into, she fits that description very very well. Almost too well. I genuinely don't see any faults with her, and i knew her for a good portion of university. Both on a personality level (modest, very kind, sweet, reserved, introverted) and look wise as well (11/10 looks).

3) I may get some hate or hurtful accusations from this point, but I'm a relatively ugly guy. I've been on a few dates with some girls, and had a "relationship" when I was much younger, but never one in my adult life. I've met girls online, talked to them over the phone and had a great time, then shared pictures and been instantly blocked. I'm not going to dwell on this but the point I'm making, I haven't had many (or pretty much any girl) show interest in me, unless I ask them out then some have gone on dates with me. The idea that I had a girl, very nearly the girl of my dreams, basically constantly ask for my attention and show very blatantly signs of interested and only for me to ignore her is very hard for me to swallow, taking into consideration the context that no other girl has done that. Let alone a girl that fits very much into my "type" and I would have been very happy to be with her.

4) This girl ended up dating one of my friends friend, and knowing what I know about him, he's not really the kind of guy to stick around, and from what my friend has mentioned he basically used her then dumped her some time later. I'm not trying to say I would have "saved" her, or that it would even work out between us, but I definitely am not the kind of person to use someone, and the guy she unfortunately ran into was, and this was the outcome.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28346577

This realization and thought processed has been simmering in my head over the course of nearly a year, and it progressively has gotten worse and worse as I grasp the gravity of the situation: I may have treated a kind hearted girl, who had a thing for me, like absolute shit after she treated me with the kindness no other woman has treated me with some of the most blatant acts of affection, only for me to completely ignore her, and then leave her to a guy who just pumped and dumped her.

The gut wrenching part of this is that I simply do not know. Was she genuinely interested in me and I blundered horribly, or was my initial understanding of the situation correct (she was just a possibly-fake nice girl being nice for a grade, or just being nice for the sake of niceness). Or maybe she was being nice in an effort to friendzone me and use me as a shoulder to cry on / therapist. I simply do not know because I never even asked her out, and it never occurred to me at all. I always kept my distance and never acted even in a friendly manner, let alone romantic. I truly wish that my initial understand was correct, it would give me so much relief to know that there never was an opportunity for me to take in the first place. But to know that the opportunity was there, and I screwed it up in such a horrible, inhumane and mean way, genuinely makes me want to vomit.

I haven't seen her in years, and I'm dwelling on a past thing, but this realization is coming very late and at a time when I'm very much alone. I have good friends and family I can find solace in, but especially since I don't meet any new girls anymore (since I'm out of college), this past situation is haunting me.

Ultimately you probably won't get over your depression without addressing whatever had made you that way. Therapy is worthwhile if you can afford it.

Until then, pick something you don't like about yourself. Something small and self-contained. Maybe you don't like your hair, or your clothes, or the state of your room. Fix it, then stand back and admire your work.

Ignore the voice telling you it's all pointless. That isn't you, that's depression brain. It might've been your friend at one point, but that time is over and you need to start telling it to fuck off.

Suicidal thoughts are as bad as any addictive drug. They're warm and fuzzy and inviting and you need to get them out of your life.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28346692
If I was there I'd hug you.

People who haven't been where you are will hear that kind of talk and think you're being dramatic or that you actually hate yourself, but I know the truth because I've been there. I know that talking and thinking about yourself like that doesn't come from a place of hate. It feels good, doesn't it. It feels right. Like a warm blanket. It's a cozy place you can retreat to where the rest of the world's bullshit doesn't actually matter.

It's the depression talking. Depression is your brain's way of protecting you and keeping you going when things are bad. It was your friend, and in a way it still is, but some friendships aren't meant to last. You need to try to let go of it.

Here's something that helped me. It sounds stupid, but bear with me. Every morning, go to the bathroom mirror and look yourself in the eyes. Say out loud "I'm going to take care of you today". Repeat it a few times. You'll feel stupid about it. Push through that. I broke down crying the first few times I did this, but after a while it became something I looked forward to. It felt like the depression voice had some competition.

After that, have a shower and clean yourself well, then decide on one thing you can do that will make you feel a little better and resolve do it whether your depression brain wants to or not. Make that a daily routine. You've begun training your brain to associate that warm blanket feeling with self care rather than self deprecation.

Obviously this isn't going to fix everything on its own, but it is a start.

Let me get this out of the way: I am legitimately autistic. I don't mind, really. But I realized something that has kinda fucked me up.
>Start playing Magic the Gathering when I was about 20 in college
>Fall madly in love with the game
>So much lore to learn
>So many mechanics to piddle with
>10k+ number of cards to look at
>Thousands of articles written on the subject
>Multiple books
>Spend most of my free time reading about Magic or talking about it with nerd friends
>10 years pass
>Friends all moved away or have kids and no desire for Magic anymore
>Realize I have five grand in cardboard sitting in my hobby room that I don't play anymore
>Stop playing in paper and online
>Sell all cards
>Stop visiting /tg/ almost entirely
>Catch myself getting excited when I can mention something about the game
>Wife points out that I still geek out when telling old stories about tournaments or playing with friends
>Realize that all of my other hobbies aren't as in-depth, or at least don't feel that way
>Too dumb to learn more about Arduino than I already do
>Don't want to write music daily because I get writer's block and mentally burn out
>Fortnite doesn't feel as deep as Magic from a gameplay standpoint
>Only friends left are those that play Fortnite

SO: marry your girl, find a small place, and get ready for your kid.
Hints: don't buy expense stuff - goodwill, thrift stores, consignment shops, etc. Kids grow out of clothes and other stuff FAST so whenever possible get used.

Add in a supportive community, a chance for charity networking, moral and ethical guidance for the little one, it might just be what you and your new wife need spiritually, too.
And truly, deeply - congrats and good luck!

Promoters use a single ticket vendor for events. Anyone selling tickets to the event that isn't the official ticket vendor is either a scalper or a scammer.

You can tell a scam for sure if the asking price is close to (or less than) the official asking price. A scalper will ask at least double if not more.

>>28346690

svr is "service fee". It's there to make it look more legitimate when in reality this is a low effort scam website. This is there about page: https://explore.seetickets.us/about/

It's the default page from the WordPress theme they're using. They've copied and pasted the about us text from the ACTUAL See Tickets website which is https://www.seetickets.com/

Here's a good rule of thumb. If a website isn't a .com, or in the case of special types of organisations .org, .edu, or .gov domain then it very likely isn't a legitimate business.

posts.com:
I'm fucked up over a stranger.

Been working at a gas station, and some months ago, a customer walks in. Ridiculously cute gothy tomboy, short-ish black hair with a green tuft toward the front, and a smile that simply denies a man all words. She'd been in a few times before, was always pleasant, soft-spoken. And this time, she asks me how I am.

Of course, being a dumbass, I start talking about the (pretty shitty DESU) laptop I'd just gotten, excited about finally catching up on semi-modern games. She brings up her own troubles with her home PC, and I basically get technical instead of the "Do you want me to look at it sometime?" I'm pretty sure she was trying to get out of me. Another customer walked in, and I rush over to the guy to get him out of the way as quickly as I can, but in seconds, she's out the door. I didn't think much of it at the time, she was a semi-regular customer already, figured I'd try to make better smalltalk next time. Then I blinked, and nearly four months went by, waiting without even realizing I was waiting. But with how quickly I rushed to the guy, I never asked anything personal, couldn't even get myself to look her in the eye. My dumb ass didn't even ask her name.

She thought I didn't like her.

She's probably already with someone by now, and she is a literal stranger; it's totally possible that she has traits that would be a deal-breaker for me, or I'd have traits that would be a deal-breaker for her. I just wish I'd actually put myself in a position to find out, one way or the other.

Maybe this is just mental illness. I dunno.

Hope she's okay.

posts.com:
I'd like to expand on the topic more than the previous post.
Recently I recognized daydreaming/obsessive thinking (like in pic rel) to be one of my main problems. Why is it such as issue? I've been reading 'Rational Recovery' which is mostly about alcohol, but that book inspired stuff like easypeasy, so the method can be applied to anything: porn, drugs, alcohol, social media. The gist is that you have to recognize any desire to drink or use as not actually being a part of you, but as a voice of the midbrain, the less developed part of your animalistic brain, which contacts with your neocortex, and gives it various ideas. Basically, you give your full consent to act on your impulses, while being nudged by this primitive desire. The key is to recognize the voice in your head, with all its little copes and justifications (ex: im so lonely, only drinking will help me). I tried this method, and discovered something peculiar about myself...my thinking process is completely fucked due to years of daydreaming, i dont think like a normal human anymore. I dont think like most normal beings do, reflecting on their present with their inner monologue. Instead, my inner voice is solely focused on various random scenarios in my head ("oh, what if i asked that cutie shy girl, and it suddenly turns out that she really like fallout, just like me, wouldnt that be awesome?!" ). So i think you can see the problem here. I cant exactly detect the primitive voice, if i dont have it. My actions are mostly automated, with my voice being occupied by random shit. I seek your advice, for i feel desperate. Has anyone been dealing with the same problem? im trying to genuinely look for an answer without havning to see a therapist, but that seems like my only option at this point. I tried going on walks like some anons suggested, but i keep daydreaming even outside. I try to focus on the present, analyse my surroundings to keep the voice in my head focused, nothing works. share stories

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
> If you had a big lump sum of money like 100k in savings, how would you use it to make a million?
A good way of thinking about investing isn't
>How much money do I want to make?
it's
>How much money do I want to make, and on what timetable?
Because the timetable dictates what options someone can use.

If you have only one hour to make a million dollars, you'd want to take all your money to the casino or racetrack and make the fairest single 8x bet you could make, then pray. The risk is overwhelmingly bad, but something like 1 in 9 tries you end up a millionaire. If you had a week, you could buy or sell trade short expiry options. If sold options blow up you're a debtor for life, and if bought options don't hit you're penniless, but if it pays out, it's either small "free money" or you make more money than god.

If you had a financial quarter to a year, you could trade long expiry options, volatile shitcoins, or bust ass and launch a startup with the money as a seed. Most businesses go under, most shitcoins are scams, and most options expire worthless, but out of many losers, a handful do win. If you had two years, you could spend it on going to trade school for a trade that'll make you 100k/yr or an MBA if you went to college for 200k/yr jobs. You'll make a million in 5-13 years that way, assuming you budget tightly. If you had four years, you could go to a four year university. A median bachelor's degree holder makes $2.8 million over a lifetime.

If you had 6-10ish years, you could invest in index funds, their average returns are about 10% and compound. If you have 10-20ish years, you could work a normal white collar job while investing - median US pay is $54,132 a year, you'll cross a million somewhere in that range.

There are other investments, but seeing the time brackets is the important insight. Faster is generally riskier. I make no judgment what is "best", it comes down to personal preference and risk tolerance.

I'm sorry to say but if you are talking about calories and simple not eating, then I don't think you know as much about nutrition as you think you do.It kind of understand given all the conflicting info. (I didn't figure myself out till I was 21 and that was only thanks to some very odd situations I got into) Mainly because there are different types of people so different diets work differently. We keep acting like one diet will fix everyone, but one size fits all is clearly wrong.

It's not just calories, its type of calories and other things your body needs. Calorie restriction is too abstract to be useful as it only looks at total energy, heck it doesn't even consider how the calories are absorbed or what things your body needs to use them for. I recommend finding a ratio of Fat, Carb and Protein they works with your body. Along with a powdered multi vitamin to help supplement given how nutrition poor most food is today. And eating fresh and organic foods as processing adds lots of stuff everyone should avoid.

General things like avoiding sugar helps a lot for most people, but few understand how much sugar is really in our foods, its very hard to avoid. Pic is some common ratios for bodybuilders as they understand how macro nutrition ratios effect how their body reacts, granted each person is unique but its a good place to start. Keto is hard for many to get started, so a more gradual transition can help.

In most cases I believe the reason many keep having a craving to eat is they haven't given their body what it wants. For example lets say your diet lacks X, well your body will keep telling you to eat till it gets X, so eating an endless amount of Y doesn't help you at all. Most diets are just some reformulation of a macro nutrition ratio, which works really well for like 10% of people. It gets picked up by the mainstream, then later gets dropped when people find it hurts the other 90%, because different people have different dietary needs.

after Macro Nutrition (fat, carb, protein) and Nutrition (vitamins and minerals) you'll find other factors you'll also need to figure out like
Hydration (getting enough water)
Sleep cycles (sleeping enough and in regular intervals)
Microbiome (making sure you have the good bacteria in you body to help you)
Bowel moments (how often you use the bathroom and what does it look like, it's a bit gross but it tells you a lot that can help)
Exercise Muscle (building muscles makes your body burn more fat as you have more muscles mass that needs energy, this helps with weight loss but can increase your total weight as muscle adds on)
Exercise Cardio (this helps with energy levels and body regulations, not as big for weight loss but a minimum is needed to be healthy overall)
Lifestyle stress (both emotional and chemical, these are hard to pin down but if you have stress your body is basically posing itself as it panics even if you don't notice)

The order and priority is debatable, but each one can trigger good results and getting these all down and more really helps. remember their is not simple answer, you are an insanely complex bio engine so figuring out how to fix you is not going to be simple. Alternatively you could actually have some health issue that is triggering it, but going addressing these usually fixes those as well along the way. Wish you the best of luck, oh and keep a detail log of everything that data can be hugely helpful at isolating the issues.

posts.name: jimbo
posts.com:
Yea OP, in some ways I think it's understandable you feel your childhood was robbed. And that must really suck to feel that way! :-( I'm sad to read it honestly...

However, "this is your life now". Watch Tim Dillon's segment on "adults going to disney world". He basically says that, yes: some people miss out on some experiences in life, & there's nothing that can be done about it besides accepting it.

IMO, daily meditation helps immensely to improve your ability to live in the moment & feel grateful for what you have. Start meditating. Work up to doing 20 minutes/ day. Start with just 1 or 2 minutes per day. Yes it's hard. Yes, the struggle is part of why it works.

As far as your social development goes: Start going out to clubs & parties & concerts. Don't even worry about meeting people yet. Just start showing up, dance a little, just enjoy it.

Start learning to socialize. "The Mystery Method" by Mystery / Erik van Markovik & "The Natural" by Richard La Ruina are basically what taught me how to talk to women & how to socialize. Learn some Neuro Linguistic Programming (the psychology thing, not the computer programming thing). Start implementing what you learn, piece by piece.

Maybe get involved with some volunteering opportunities, or a faith thing like church / temple / whatever.

Just get socializing. Make a goal to get a little bit outside your comfort zone each day (maybe just say "hi" to 2 women, or even strike up a conversation with a man. Whatever.)

I believe you can improve your life, Anon. Be sure to always practice gratitude.

>If i asked you on a date would you say yes?
I haven't a clue. I don't know what you look like, what you sound like, or what you smell like. I don't know how you hold yourself, whether you seem confident, whether you're funny, whether you come across as basically decent/kind/compassionate/respectful or whether you seem like an arrogant, conceited, selfish prick. The answer would depend on things like that.

>What if you were desperately enough?
That question suggests a rather profound lack of understanding about an extremely important difference between men and women.

Men, in my experience, are at least very slightly attracted to most women. It may be only slight; but if you're desperate enough, horny enough, drunk enough, then who knows? Contrast that with how you feel about other men (assuming you're straight): it doesn't matter how desperate, or horny, or drunk you are, you're still not going to have sex with an unattractive *man*, because for a man you actually feel no attraction *at all*. And that is quite definitely different from feeling slight attraction.

Now, when it comes to how women feel about men, we don't feel that kind of slight attraction. If we're attracted to a man, we are just as strongly attracted to him as you could ever be to a woman; but if we're not, then we're REALLY not. If we're not attracted to a guy, then we're not attracted to him in the same way that you are not attracted to an unattractive man.

So, no. It doesn't matter how "desperate" I am, I won't go on a date with a man I'm not attracted to, for exactly the same reason that you wouldn't put yourself on Grindr because you're desperate.

>inb4 incels screeching about Chad

For the record, women can be attracted to men for all kinds of reasons that have nothing at all to do with looks. That doesn't change the fact that if we're not attracted to you, we're REALLY not attracted.
